name: Inuyama Castle
short_description: One of Japan’s only five castles with an original wooden keep.
description: Perched on a hill overlooking the Kiso River, Inuyama is one of the oldest original fortresses in Japan. Unlike the reconstructed concrete castles in larger cities, this structure features steep wooden stairs and a wrap-around balcony at the top with no safety netting, offering an authentic (and slightly thrilling) view of the river and surrounding plains.

name: Narayai-juku
short_description: The longest and best-preserved post town on the Nakasendo trail.
description: While Magome and Tsumago get the most tourists, Narai-juku offers a more expansive and lived-in atmosphere. Known as 'Narai of a Thousand Houses,' it was the wealthiest post town on the route. The preserved wooden buildings stretch for a kilometer, housing lacquerware shops and traditional inns that feel frozen in the Edo period.

name: Eiheiji Temple
short_description: The 'Temple of Eternal Peace' and headquarters of Soto Zen.
description: Founded in 1244, this massive complex consists of over 70 buildings nestled in a cedar forest. It is an active monastery where you can watch monks performing their daily rituals. The architecture is connected by covered wooden walkways, and the ceiling of the Sanshikaku hall is decorated with 230 stunning paintings of birds and flowers.

name: Achi Village (Star Village)
short_description: Certified as the best place in Japan for stargazing.
description: Located in the southern Japanese Alps, this village uses its high altitude and low light pollution to offer 'Star Tours.' Visitors take a gondola to an elevation of 1,400 meters at night. When the lights are switched off at the summit, the Milky Way becomes visible with startling clarity. It is a romantic, quiet alternative to the neon-lit cities.

name: Tojinbo Cliffs
short_description: Rare hexagonal basalt columns battered by the Sea of Japan.
description: These unique geological formations are found in only three places in the world. The columns have been carved by centuries of rough waves, creating a jagged, dramatic coastline. You can walk right to the edge of the 25-meter cliffs or take a sightseeing boat to see the scale of the formations from the water.

name: Gujo Hachiman (Food Replica Workshops)
short_description: The 'Water City' and Japan’s capital of wax food models.
description: Famous for its pristine water canals that run through the streets, this town is also the birthplace of the hyper-realistic plastic food seen in Japanese restaurant windows. Several workshops allow you to try making your own wax lettuce or tempura. It’s a quirky, hands-on craft experience in a beautiful riverside setting.

name: Kurobe Gorge Railway
short_description: An open-air 'torokko' train through Japan’s deepest V-shaped gorge.
description: Originally built for dam construction, this narrow-gauge railway now takes passengers through spectacular mountain scenery. The open-sided cars provide unobstructed views of emerald rivers, bright red bridges, and secluded hot springs like Kanetsuri, where you can dig your own bath in the riverbank.

name: Sekigahara Town
short_description: The site of the most important battle in samurai history.
description: In 1600, this valley saw the battle that unified Japan under the Tokugawa Shogunate. The town is now a sprawling open-air museum where you can visit the specific hilltop campsites of famous generals like Ishida Mitsunari and Tokugawa Ieyasu. A modern museum offers VR experiences of the battle, but the real charm is walking the quiet fields where history was decided.

name: Myoryuji (Ninja Temple)
short_description: A temple filled with trapdoors, hidden stairs, and secret passages.
description: While not actually built by ninjas, this temple was a disguised fortress for the Maeda lords. It looks like a two-story building from the outside but has seven internal levels. Guided tours lead you through 29 secret staircases, hidden lookouts, and an escape tunnel disguised as a well. Booking by phone is mandatory and it’s a favorite for fans of clever architecture.

name: Chirihama Nagisa Driveway
short_description: The only beach in Japan where you can drive your car on the sand.
description: The sand here is uniquely fine and compacted, making it hard enough for regular cars, buses, and motorcycles to drive right along the water's edge. This 8km stretch on the Noto Peninsula offers a rare sense of freedom, especially at sunset. Local stalls along the beach sell grilled clams and sea snails during the summer months.
